step1.para: The cab air switch in the instrument panel has two positions. In the RUN position, the valve is closed. Placing the valve in the DUMP position opens the valve and directs air pressure to the pilot valves located near the height control valves. With the cab air switch in the DUMP position, a ground circuit is closed, illuminating a warning light on the instrument panel. Refer to the circuit diagram furnished with vehicle.
With the cab air controls, the rear hosing incorporates the pilot valve as follows:

step2.para: The air supply to the height control valves comes from the pressure protection valve. Air is delivered from the height control valves to the pilot valves (one on each side), which distribute air to the right and left air spring systems. The pilot valve has no other function with the cab control valve in the RUN position.

Placing the cab air switch in the DUMP position directs air to each pilot valve causing it to stop the air supply to the air springs and dump the air from the air springs through the exhaust port on the bottom of the pilot valves.
Placing the cab air switch back into the RUN position returns air spring control to the height control valves and the air springs will inflate until the vehicle is level.
